text:
Students took off their hardcore hangouts for the sake of money, in the end they got the money themselves
07 Nov 2019, 20:55 by Ilya Sidorov
For eight years, I‚Äôm Shmacked (I‚Äôm in g *** o) posted videos of parties from various US universities. Rollers gained from 100 to 500 thousand views.
Most of the videos were shot by the students themselves. They paid money for the opportunity to Instagram I‚Äôm Shmacked at their college. In exchange for this, they were promised earnings of up to $ 30 thousand.
It soon became clear that the head of I‚Äôm Shmacked turned out to be a scammer. He took money, but did not keep his promises. The victims began to receive threats.
What did I‚Äôm Shmacked do and why did students give her money


Arya Tufanian

I‚Äôm Shmacked was founded in 2011 by amateur director Jeffrey Ray and student Arya Tufanian. At that time they were 19 and 20 years old respectively.
At first, they traveled around the United States and filmed parties. The videos were uploaded to their YouTube channel, which quickly gained popularity. He currently has 41.6 thousand subscribers, and the total number of views is slightly more than 7 million.
Example of shooting a party at the University of Miami (I'm at *** about: University of Miami. Weekend)



In 2016, Tufanian invited students to organize events, shoot videos, and upload them to their college‚Äôs I‚Äôm Shmacked. The best works were uploaded to I‚Äôm Shmacked verified account with 1.2 million subscribers.

Students had to pay between $ 45 and 500 to become a company representative at their college.

In addition to popularity, they were promised earnings from the sale of merchandise, advertising and entry to the party.
In 2017, 3600 students from various US universities joined I‚Äôm Shmacked.
Users almost immediately realized that they were being deceived
Instagrams with video quickly gained popularity. Over time, their administrators began to suspect that they were the victim of scammers.
Some colleges had several I‚Äôm Shmacked accounts. When Tufanian was informed about this, he said that they were fakes and promised to achieve their blocking.
Yale University Party Example



Shops with merch were created very rarely. Students did not receive any percentage of sales.
I worked at a campus store for $ 9.25 per hour. I was just hoping I would beat back the money I paid them a month ago. Arun Singh became I‚Äôm Shmacked Ambassador at Pennsylvania College in September 2018.
Tufanian often organized parties himself and sold tickets for them. But at the last moment they were canceled. Money was not returned to anyone.
In many cases, after students paid a membership fee, Tufanian did not get in touch.
Participants began to receive threats
One of the users created an instagram page where he posted screenshots of Tufanian‚Äôs correspondence with deceived students. Tufanian contacted the account administrator and threatened to sue libel.
Tufanian did not sue, but he was still feared.
In 2016, he demanded through the court that Gawker Media remove two articles about him. According to Tufanian, there was slander in the publications.
In 2014, he threatened a Business Insider journalist with petitions for dismissal and deportation. She did not link to I‚Äôm Shmacked in her article.
I‚Äôm Shmacked employees were not paid salaries, they worked in Tufanian‚Äôs homes


Arya Tufanian

From 2016 to 2018, Tufanian ran his company from a pair of rented houses in Los Angeles. Many employees of the company did not have positions and contracts.
I‚Äôm Shmacked had a big turnover. Mostly interns worked in the houses of Tufanian. Every day they talked with students, trying to get them to pay hundreds of dollars to join the company.
Almost all correspondence was conducted through a verified I‚Äôm Shmacked account. Sometimes there were so many posts that Instagram blocked sending them.
Tufanian promised his employees to pay salaries from the second month. The first four weeks they worked for free.
When people quit, Tufanian was looking for new employees through Instagram stories.
Students still maintain I‚Äôm Shmacked accounts


Instagram I‚Äôm Shmacked Florida Atlantic University.

Some deceived students still maintain I‚Äôm Shmacked pages in their colleges.
Bradley Gasparovich, the administrator of I‚Äôm Shmacked at the University of Michigan, paid several hundred dollars to join the company. After that, Tufanian unsubscribed from him and blocked.
Despite this, Gasparovich continued to lead the I‚Äôm Shmacked instagram and already gained more than 7 thousand subscribers. He uploads party videos and tells other users not to collaborate with Tufanian.
What's up with I‚Äôm Shmacked
I‚Äôm Shmacked account is locked. Tufanian's personal page with 175 thousand subscribers is still available.
The head of the company does not comment on the charges; no criminal case was brought against him. Nobody returned the money to the students, and they are unlikely to receive it. [The New York Times]
